column89: Flight Crew Took Evasive Action; Flight Crew FLC Overrode Automation; Flight Crew Became Reoriented
column92: This is more of an FYI regarding the new software being uploaded into the ACARS. During our preflight we got to experience the new software. It took us a few minutes to get familiar with it. Before the flight started; we scrolled through all the screens. One screen in particular caused an issue; it was the screen marked >7500. I don't recall selecting anything; but somehow Dispatch immediately send an ACARS message asking to call him. So I immediately picked up my cell phone and called. He said he received a hijack message absent any info but the flight number and thought it odd since we're at the gate and had barely started boarding. I assured him all was fine and that we were just scrolling through the new ACARS screens. While on the phone with the dispatcher; I tested the DNES button by pushing it; oddly enough; he got no message; so I'm not even sure if that function is active yet.I reviewed the ACARS bulletin associated with this update. It states that a 7500 message is auto sent if you leave the page up for 2 minutes. The only other possibility is the send button marked DNES was pushed which happens to be next to the RETURN to menu button. It's hard to figure because it seemed as if I went through those pages fairly quickly. My best guess that I got interrupted just long enough by the boarding agent; maintenance or the flight attendant. I'm sure this will happen more often as pilots begin to encounter the new software. Personally; I think there should be a requirement to manually SEND such a message and/or the SENT (DNES) button (key 5L) is moved away from the RETURN button (key 6L). I can't imagine a situation wherein you can get to this page; yet not have the extra micro second to hit the SEND button. If the threat was that great; I can assure you that you'd never get to that page to start with. It is also confusing as to what 'DNES' stands for. Why not just label it 'SEND' because such a message should be an assurance of intent.This is a good FYI; because the last thing we need to happen is for someone to be scrolling through the screens enroute and unintentionally leave the >7500 page up while attending to other duties.
column96: A B757 Captain discovered after a new ACARS software installation that when an ACARS screen marked '>7500' is left up for more than two minutes; 7500 code is automatically sent to alert Dispatch of an unwanted situation.

column84: Deviation - Procedural Published Material / Policy
column89: Flight Crew Rejected Takeoff; Flight Crew Became Reoriented
column92: On the takeoff roll; after calling out 'thrust set'; I scanned the EICAS engine indications; and then I fixated on the altimeter confusing it for the airspeed indicator. When the numbers on the altimeter dial did not increase during the takeoff roll I mistakenly believed it was a stuck airspeed indication and called for an aborted takeoff. The captain aborted the takeoff and we taxied in to a location where we could talk to maintenance. As I was explaining to the Captain what I had seen I realized my mistake; I had confused the Altimeter indication for the Airspeed. There were no problems with the aircraft and we completed the flight safely.
column94: As we discussed the problem the first officer realized that he had become fixated on the altimeter not the airspeed indicator and there was not actually a problem with the airspeed indicator. Once we had established that there was nothing wrong with the aircraft we continued the flight normally.
column96: During the takeoff roll an EMB-145 First Officer call for a reject after scanning his instruments and interpreting the 0 altimeter indication as an airspeed indicator failure.

column84: Deviation - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Deviation - Procedural Clearance; Inflight Event / Encounter CFTT / CFIT; Inflight Event / Encounter Unstabilized Approach
column87: Person Flight Crew; Person Air Traffic Control
column89: Air Traffic Control Issued Advisory / Alert; Flight Crew Became Reoriented
column92: I was the pilot flying; the Captain was the pilot monitoring  After briefing the approach for 36L; with my concurrence; our approach was changed to 36R and we were issued a vector to intercept the Final Approach course; though not cleared for the approach   I initially misunderstood these instructions and wanted to hit the approach arm button; but Captain explained that we should arm the Localizer only in order to prevent an erroneous descent before intercepting the glide slope   As a consequence of this sound advice; I completely forgot to arm the Approach mode when the Final Controller issued the 'Cleared for the ILS 36R' instructions  I don't think I heard the approach clearance - as I know I didn't acknowledge it at the time   This failure on my part went unrecognized by me; though I could see that we were going above glide slope - after I had put the gear down; slowed down; selected final flaps and was completely configured but was also completely confounded as to why the airplane wasn't descending! I got some guidance from the Captain and was descending towards the glide slope but not as quickly as was required to meet the stabilized approach criteria   Around 1;500 feet AGL; the Captain announced that he had the airplane; clicked off the autopilot and descended towards the glide slope   At around 1;200feet AGL; we simultaneously broke out of the clouds in to VMC conditions and passed through the glide slope while the Captain re-engaged the Autopilot; rearmed the Approach mode and offered me the flight controls   With the runway in sight; I took control of the airplane and leveled off as we were slightly below the VASI; and at the same time; the Control Tower announced that we were below glide slope and they had a low altitude alert on our approach.  I then flew the VASI glide slope indications to a normal; uneventful landing  We talked/debriefed at the gate; and I've had some time to reflect on what I did/didn't do   What I learned and will do from now on; is to announce out loud as soon as I am confused   I thought the Approach Mode was engaged and would have sworn to it!  My experience level wasn't enough to see my mistake and correct it before the Captain had to intervene   Ultimately; I'm certain we were safe and had the option to go around and I will chalk this approach lesson up to one that I can learn from but not repeat! When in doubt of your own actions or the actions of your fellow crew members:  say so out loud!  Never hesitate to speak up when your comfort level has been exceeded.
column94: I was the Captain and pilot monitoring  The First Officer (FO) has very low time in the right seat of the 777 and is apparently unused to flying long-haul all-nighters; so it is natural that he was having a little trouble keeping up with the rapidly changing nature of this particular approach  Our runway was changed; 'with our approval'; from 36L to 36R; then in quick succession we were cleared direct to the ZZZ fix; then cleared down to 3;000 feet; then given a right turn to intercept the LOC just outside the ZZZ fix  At this point there was some confusion about whether we had been cleared for the approach; with the FO thinking we were; 'though we were not yet'; and wanting to arm approach mode this resulted in a brief discussion; followed shortly by another one about whether or not he was required to extend the centerline from the FAF.  At about this time; I mentioned that we were getting close to the final approach segment and ought to start slowing and configuring.  During this time we were cleared for the approach; but the FO did not mentally register this so he did not then arm Approach Mode to permit intercepting the glideslope (GS).  This resulted in us remaining at 3;000 feet in altitude hold mode as we passed through the GS.  The Relief Officer (FB) and I were making suggestions to help him; but I now believe we might inadvertently have been distracting him; making it more difficult for him to get his situational awareness back  As a result; we were coming down slowly; still well above the GS; and I could see that at the current rate we would not get down to it before having to go around.  Fortunately; we broke out of the clouds between 1;200 feet and 1;100 feet AGL and were in visual conditions for the rest of the approach and landing; so I realized we had brief window in which to get down to the GS before reaching the required stabilized approach minimum altitude of 500 feet for visual conditions  Otherwise we would have executed a missed approach at 1;000 feet; as is required in IMC.  Therefore I briefly took control of the aircraft; disconnected the autopilot; and established a higher rate of descent for a few seconds to get us back to a position where we could be fully stabilized and on the proper visual descent path by 500 feet.  Then I reconnected the autopilot; armed approach mode; and returned control to the FO.  Immediately after this; the tower called to relay that they were receiving a low altitude alert on us and to check our instruments.  I responded that we were visual.  The FO completed the approach and landing in an excellent manner.We conducted an extensive and very constructive debrief in the cockpit after completing the parking checklist; and we agreed that since no regulations had been violated; and the operation was never unsafe; that a report would not be necessary.  However; I was advised this afternoon that it might be a good idea to file one anyway just in case there were any questions about what had happened; so here it is.  Would I do anything differently if presented with a similar situation? Yes; absolutely  I had been allowing the FO to dig himself a hole so that he could better learn from the experience; but 'though that was very valuable once to me as an FO myself'; I shouldn't expect it to be the best method of learning for everyone.  And anyway; I let the hole get too deep before stepping in and taking control.  In the future; I will be more strongly directive earlier in the situation; take control sooner if necessary; and rely much more on the debrief for teaching.
column96: B777 flight crew describes an un-stabilized approach caused in part by fatigue and very low time in the seat by the First Officer and the Captain allowing the First Officer to get a little too far behind before taking over.

column84: ATC Issue All Types; Deviation - Procedural Published Material / Policy; Inflight Event / Encounter CFTT / CFIT
column89: General None Reported / Taken
column92: While executing the LDA DME 25 into EGE in CAVOK weather conditions; we received a low altitude warning from the ATC tower controller. We were descending on the RNAV arrival in managed mode on the Airbus and was coming from 'VOAXA intersection' to 'AQULA intersection' descending from 13;800 feet to 12;900 feet that is charted. The aircraft did start a little higher descent rate out of 13;800 feet to 12;900 feet to cross 'AQULA intersection' at 12;900 feet but was right on path at that fix {AQULA} . Speed was coming from I believe 180 knots down to 160 knots at that same time. That is when ATC showed an Altitude Alert and to check altitude and altimeter setting {30.48 I believe}. Ridge line was in plain sight and no other issues after that.
column94: We were about 170 knots above or at all altitudes on the approach. The altimeter settings were correct with the latest tower call about 2 min earlier. We were in very clear VFR conditions and there was no indication from the cockpit there was any issue with terrain.
column96: ATC called an Airbus crew with a low altitude alert while the aircraft was on the LDA DME RWY 25 to EGE descending at slightly higher than normal rate but on profile with the terrain in sight.

column92: We were cleared for the EDGAR 1B arrival into MMUN; landing on RW30L. We checked the step-down points and found an error at the fix: EDGAR. It's published on the Jepp plate as 280/FL 390BFL340A. However; the arrival loaded into the Pegasus FMC with: 280/FL320BFL340A. Since it is impossible to be 'below FL320' and 'above FL 340'; we changed the fix data in the FMC. I don't know what the plane would have actually flown in this case. The data in the FMC must be reliable.
column96: Captain states that while the EDGAR1B arrival to MMUN shows crossing EDGAR between FL390 and FL340 at 280 knots; the FMC showed the crossing as 280/FL320BFL340A which is not possible.

column92: On the ACCRA SID out of MKE after 10;000 feet; we indicated 300K.  When Center said we could resume normal speed we then saw on chart that 250 knots was the speed.  We both checked and talked about the SID before pushback and did not see speed restriction. The 250 speed restriction needs to be easier to notice.
column96: The flight crew of an air carrier twin jet departing MKE on the ACCRA RNAV SID failed to note the restriction to maintain 250 knots until advised by ATC. They cited the format of the chart as a contributing factor.
